text:
"Entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge in 1857" p.227

Pelletreau, William S.

Early New York houses with historical-genealogical notes.
New York: Francis P. Harper, 1900.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Entrance to Brooklyn Bridge in 1857.]

text:
General View: Lower Manhatten, showing Piers of Brooklyn Bridge. Work began about 1870, and taking 13 years to complete Bridge, Roeblings: Engineers.
Urbrocks Collection
title: General view - Lower Manhattan.

text:
(2)

A general view westward from the Brooklyn Bridge (under construction), over the Cherry Hill section, Printing House Square, City Hall Commons and westward to the Hudson (North) River. Shown in the foreground, is the Manhattan abutment of the bridge, with the Roosevelt Street Ferry to Broadway, Brooklyn adjoining. Points of interest shown are, U.S. Post Office, Tribune Building, Harper's and the Newsboy's Home.

About 1870-1875.

Brown Brothers.

Published in the American on December 1908, and the New York Times of October 20, 1912.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.

text:
A general view westward from the incompleted Brooklyn Bridge. In the background is the North (Hudson) River and its far Jersey shore. Silhouetted against same are the Post Office and the Tribune building.

1876

American Studio
Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.

text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construction, with the "Catwalk" and Manhattan anchorage in the foreground. Also shown is a general view westward over the City Hall and Printing House Square area, to the Hudson River, with its Jersey shore line just beyond. Note how the U.S. Post Office and the Tribune Buildings predominated at this date.

About 1878-1879.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.

text:
(1) Manhattan end of Brooklyn Bridge, while under construction.
About 1880.

(2) The same, another view.
About 1880.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan end of the bridge, while under construction.]

text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construction and showing the stone supports and cable, prior to the laying of the cat walk. This view is northeastward from Manhattan and shows the Brooklyn shore in the background. Note the masted schooners in the foreground on the South Street waterfront.

About 1880.

Gift of H.D. Jewett.

Two additional views of the same structure; one of which is similar in direction to the above, the other being photographed from Brooklyn.

About 1880

Gift of George T. Bagoe
No. 86 Madison Avenue.

1299 B2 NEG. #4352

1299-B3

text:

Brooklyn Bridge, during the latter part of its construction, as seen from a Manhattan pier, looking north east. Ferry "Somerset" is seen plying its route.
About 1882.

Gubelman

About 1885.

title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge from a Manhattan pier.]

text: View from the Tribune Building of the uncompleted Brooklyn Bridge. n.d., but prior to 1883, at which time the Bridge was dedicated and opened.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the uncompleted Brooklyn Bridge from New York Tribune building.]
A union of hearts and a union of hands

text:
(1)
Throng of sight-seeing public visited the Brooklyn Bridge, to walk its length during its construction, and especially after its completion. The then marvel of engineering, was continually thronged with large crowds, as the view shows.
About 1884.

Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

(2)
The same; a later positive copy.
About 1884.

Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the sightseeing public walking the length of Brooklyn Bridge during its construction.]

text: (3) The same; a later negative copy. About 1884. Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.

text:
Brooklyn Bridge, viewed southwestward from Brooklyn and showing same spanning the East River to Manhattan. Underneath the bedway, in the center, is the financial district with the spire of Trinity Church predominating. Outstanding at the right is the distinctive
Tribune Building.

About 1890
Mildenburg, photo
P. L. Sperr Collection
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [East River - Manhattan.]

text:
Brooklyn Bridge, viewed northeastward from Manhattan and showing this engineering triumph spanning the East River to Brooklyn. In the foreground is the locality, better known as "The Swamp," an area populated by leather tanners.

About 1890

Mildenburg, photo
P. L. Sperr Collection
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the Swamp, an area populated by leather tanners.]

text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A view of the Manhattan end, with its train shed.  Note the cables used for the train propulsion on the bridge incline.  Prominently shown, is the dome of the Pulitzer (World) Building, with the spire of the Tribune Building southward.

About 1890.

Brown Brothers.

text:
1- Brooklyn Bridge, looking southeast towards Brooklyn; from atop the Manhattan Bridge, at Canal Street.

2- Brooklyn Bridge approach from Brooklyn. Manhattan Bridge and uptown Manhattan are also seen in this view.

3- Brooklyn Bridge's majestic suspension has been adjudged the engineering masterpiece of its time. Manhattan Bridge is also seen.

P. L. Sperr

text:
A general view of lower Manhattan as photographed northeastward from a point over Battery Park . This is at the lower right; at the lower left is West Street. Across the top is the district north of Wall Street. In the right is the East River and its Brooklyn Bridge. Under construction is the new Wall Street edifice, the City Bank - Farmers Trust Building.

1931

Ewing Galloway

text:
Social Conditions: Brooklyn Bonus Marchers get started to join other war veterans on their epic march to Washington. These Brooklyn marchers are crossing the Brooklyn Bridge to Manhattan on June 6, 1932

Associated Press Photo

June 6, 1932

text:
(1)
Brooklyn Bridge: The pedestrian walk atop the Bridge. The view is westward towards Manhattan. Note the Woolworth Building on the left.
About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.S.

(2)
A view in the same direction, slightly northward, showing the Municipal Building and the Federal Courts Building; the latter under construction.
June 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
(views 1 & 2 not dry mount items).

(3)
Similar to No. 2 and showing the Federal Court Building completed.
May 24, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).

text:

View 2 is south on the East River and shows the Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges and the Lower Manhattan skyline.

P. L. Sperr

View 2: September 16, 1935

text:
A general view of lower Manhattan, as seen from the Brooklyn Bridge, showing the Wall Street outline; predominant on which is the 60 Wall Street Tower.

About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.P.S.

For another photo from the Brooklyn Bridge by Dr. Wishengrad, see "General Views - Lower Manhattan"

title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Wall Street outline - Lower Manhattan skyline.]

text:
The Brooklyn Bridge and it's Manhattan approach as viewed eastward from the Municipal Building. This crosses the East River to the Brooklyn locale between the Columbia Heights area (right) and Flatbush Avenue Extension (left, approach to the Manhattan Bridge). The foreground zone has at times been known as the "Swamp" and "Cherry Hill".

April 1940

George D. Chinn

The two small snapshots made in 1898, the gift of Mrs. A. Gould, have no restrictions.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - Manhattan approach.

text: A solitary tug chugs down the East River and under the Brooklyn Bridge. In the background is the spectacular backdrop of the towers of lower Manhattan. (Please credit the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.) (20)
title: General view - Lower Manhattan.

text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A westward view towards Manhattan. This enlargement from an original lantern slide has been reversed in the printing. The shot tower at the right should be on the left. The domed structure in the background is the Pulitzer (World) Bldg.

Date ?

Gift of Russell Freeman
New York Public Library

title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge over East River, connecting Manhattan to Brooklyn.]
Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge over East River, connecting Manhattan to Brooklyn.]

text:
FROM BROOKLYN TO NEW YORK --- TODAY AND YESTERDAY
Two views of the world famous Brooklyn Bridge as it stretches from the Brooklyn to Manhatten. Compare the two, one made today and the other "many, many years ago", and note the drastic changes that have taken place.
Photo by Underwood and Underwood
N.D.

See first photo on following plate.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge over East River, as it stretches from Brooklyn to Manhattan.]

text:
FROM BROOKLYN TO NEW YORK--TODAY AND YESTERDAY
Two views of the world famous Brooklyn Bridge as it stretches from Brooklyn toward Manhattan. Compare the two, one made today and the other "many, many years ago", and note the drastic changes that have taken place.

See preceding photo

A STUDY IN STEEL
An unusual study of the Brooklyn Bridge as it stretches from Brooklyn, N.Y., to Manhattan, across the East River. I, the distance may be seen New York's world-famous skyline.

Photographs by Underwood and Underwood.

N.D.
title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [View of the bridge over East River, as it stretches from Brooklyn to Manhattan.]
